name: nytimes
text:
As states began to reopen their economies, many experts warned it would lead to another wave of coronavirus infections.

Here's what we know about where cases are surging in the U.S. now. https://t.co/mZyPsvULiI

name: nytimes
text:
2 states stand out: Florida and South Carolina. They were among the earliest states to open up.

Now, they are among the states seeing the biggest surges. https://t.co/mZyPsvULiI https://t.co/8nNBfKpozj

name: nytimes
text:
Here are some others that reopened before mid-May. Florida and Idaho have seen a more than 10-fold increase in average daily cases since. But they’re not alone.

Florida, like 20 other states, is now pausing or reversing plans to reopen. https://t.co/mZyPsvULiI https://t.co/8bv9S6mkEI

name: nytimes
text: We're tracking how states are responding to the surging outbreaks. See how your state has reopened — and possibly closed again as coronavirus cases rise here. https://t.co/73mrPcdc9L

name: nytimes
text:
Several states that opened later have seen coronavirus cases decline. 

For example, New York, once the epicenter of the outbreak, has seen average daily case numbers plummet. The state is still reopening, but a full return to normal is a ways off. https://t.co/jWLdI4fecM https://t.co/0KyGTU1v0x

name: nytimes
text:
President Trump has blamed the growth in cases on more testing, but that alone doesn't explain the surge.

It's true the U.S. is doing nearly 3 times as many tests as earlier.

But the case growth is outpacing the testing growth in at least half of states. https://t.co/jWLdI4fecM

name: nytimes
text:
We're tracking the change in average daily coronavirus cases and testing in every state since they began reopening.

See how your state compares here. https://t.co/jWLdI4fecM

text:
